front.title: Simple CLAT Deployment in IPv6 Edge Subnets

abstract.t: The 464XLAT strategy for ensuring IPv4 connectivity through IPv6 only provider networks relies on deployment of CLAT functions in edge networks. These functions requires assignment of a specific IPv6 prefix. We propose a simple way to deploy the CLAT function in edge networks while only requiring a single /64 prefix for the IPv6 edge network. The CLAT prefix will be self-assigned from this prefix, without requiring explicit provisioning by the network provider.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The 464XLAT strategy is defined in . It ensures ensuring IPv4 connectivity through IPv6 only provider networks by deployment of IPv4 to IPv6 CLAT functions in edge networks, and IPv6 to IPv4 PLAT functions in provider networks. Each CLAT deployment requires assignment of a specific IPv6 prefix.

The standard practice in edge networks is to use the prefix delegation mechanism and obtain a single /64 network prefix from the network service provider. The CLAT deployment would in theory require an additional prefix for each network. This increases the number of prefixes required for network operation, and generally introduces friction in the deployment of CLAT functions.
In this document, we propose an alternative in which the CLAT functions self assign a /96 prefix inside the /64 prefix assigned to the home network.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

section.title: 464XLAT and CLAT deployment
section.t:
The 464XLAT transition mechanism define in relies on two successive translations:
The packet originates in an edge network as IPv4, and is routed to the default IPv4 router for the network, which implements a CLAT function.
The CLAT translates the packet from IPv4 to IPv6 according to The source IPv4 address is obtained by combining the original IPv4 source address with the local CLAT prefix. The destination IPv6 address is obtained by combining the original IPv4 source address with the PLAT prefix.
The packet is routed over IPv6 to the PLAT.
The PLAT translates the packet from IPv6 to IPv4 according to .
The packet is routed to the IPv4 destination.
The reverse translations are performed in the opposite direction.
The construction of the prefixes for IPv6/IPv4 address translators is specified in , which allows multiple prefix sizes. In what follows, we will assume that the CLAT prefix is a /96.

The simple deployment makes a set of assumptions:
The edge network advertises a /64 prefix for IPv6 Stateless Address Autoconfiguration according to .
The CLAT function is configured with the prefix of the preferred PLAT.

section.title: Self assigned subnet
section.t:
The first step is configuration of the CLAT is the configuration of an IPv6 /96 CLAT prefix. The prefix MUST BE configured by concatenating:
The /64 prefix of the local network.
A random 16 bit CLAT subnet number.
A 16 bit number chosen so that the /96 prefix is "checksum neutral" according to .
The prefix is only valid as long as the /64 prefix of the local network is valid. Similarly to what is explained in , the /96 bit prefix MUST NOT be used if the /64 bit prefix is no longer valid.
